notes: The question and purpose is usually the initial point of the groundwater modeling workflow. Typical questions and purposes, also listed in the interest of SYMPLE24 attendees are e.g., contaminant transport, prediction of future groundwater state, groundwater management.Question and purpose is ideally the first step – not an existing conceptual or mathematical model (with a numerical solution), because a conceptual model that was maybe derived for groundwater management does possibly not account for required detailed geological structures or boundary conditions that are required for a transport model to predict contaminant transport.

The conceptual model provide a qualitative representation of the area under investigation. It shows the structure,boundary conditions,relevant processes,(if possible) uncertainties,in a usually graphic format.

The mathematical model provide a suitable equation to quantify the intended processes (like groundwater flow) under consideration of the structure and extend of the conceptual model (parameters and boundary conditions).The mathematical model can be solved with analytical and numerical methods.

Be careful: As always, these cross sections are vertically exaggerated, i.e. everything looks rather dramatic.Water table gradients are rarely that steep in nature, at least not in materials that we would call aquifers and in natural environments. Things may be different near infrastructure or in very fine sediments.Remember: This situation is only possible with recharge

Situation: steady flow in a confined aquifer (here ‘per meter width’)Head is provided by two piezometers / distance L between piezometersFor this situation the general groundwater flow equation can be significantly simplifiedThis is the most simple situation that one can imaging for groundwater flow:It is an analog of the Darcy-Experiment and thus Darcy’s law does directly apply.No fancy math needed, but anyway …

Steady flow in confined aquifer from Laplace equation (1D) (eq. 4.43, 4.66  in Fetter)Laplace equation for 1D steady state flow;to derive the functions h(x) that are solutions to this differential equation,  we need to integrate 2 times with respect to x (second derivative occurs)Each integration comes with integration constants C
Constants C1 and C2 are derived by considering the boundary conditions for the problem (which is the measured head = fixed head at x = 0 and x = L)

(h2-h1)/L = hydraulic gradient IHydraulic gradient = q/K (Darcys law)We can see that the change of h in direction of x (h as a function of x) is a linear function, i.e. a straight lineWith this equation we can determine h at location x in a confined aquifer (homogenous, uniform thickness …) if we know the head at a location x0 , its hydraulic conductivity K and the flux q

This example deals with a similar situation but this time the aquifer is unconfinedConsequence: change of head h in the direction of xDupuit assumption: vertical flow is negligible so that the problem reduces to a 1D-problem (see next slide with more information about Dupuit assumptions)

In MODFLOW, hydraulic interaction between groundwater and surface water is treated by employing the “river boundary condition“, which represents a boundary condition of the third kind (= relationship between hydraulic head and discharge at the boundary, see previous page).The corresponding relationship needs values for river stage, river bottom ele-vation, and streambed conductance (to be explained later). From this, the software is able to de-termine the hydraulic head and the specific discharge.In a first step, rivers are subdivided in-to segments called “reaches“.Each of them corresponds to a model cell.Very short segments can be neglected (see figure).

Sketches on the right are valid for each model cell which is connec-ted to a river reach.For now, it is assumed that there is no unsaturated zone between the river and the groundwater table, i.e. both are in direct hyd-raulic contact.The presence of an unsaturated zone will be discussed later.
Properties of CRiv: input parameter for groundwater models,dimension L²/T,frequently determined via model calibration (= fitting model results to measured values, usually groundwater levels).

For each cell with  groundwater-surface wa-ter interaction, numerical modelling tools determi-ne one point on the graph (snapped line). Vertical projections of this point onto the coor-dinate axes yield hydrau-lic head h and flow rate QRiv.
